candidates.title: Did a Pink Volcano Erupt in New Zealand?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A video purportedly showing bright fuschia smoke billowing from a volcano frequently appears on social media, along with a claim that it shows an actual "pink volcano" erupting in New Zealand:
Pink eruption of the volcano in New Zealand
The video does not explain what chemical process might turn smoke or steam this particular shade (although with the proper dyes, it is possible to turn smoke into a veritable rainbow), but it isn't particularly relevant anyway; this video does not depict an actual volcanic eruption.
The "pink volcano" video was created by artist Filip Hodas, and was originally shared to his Facebook page in December 2016. Hodas posted the video to Instagram (with tags such as #3D, #photoshop, #render, and #animation), and provided extra insight into how the video was created in response to a query on Facebook:
pretty much! depends on what I need. In this case I layered few planes with wm maps on top of each other and added a lot of zdepth fog to blend it in.
No records of volcanos emitting bright pink smoke exist, except those created by digital artists.
candidates.description: Video purportedly showing oddly-colored smoke and steam rising from a eruption was digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The news caption "An actual \"pink volcano\" erupting in New Zealand" is contradicted by the evidence. Snopes.com explicitly debunks this claim, stating that the video depicting a pink volcano eruption is digitally manipulated and that no records of volcanoes emitting bright pink smoke exist, except those created digitally.  The source identifies the video as a creation by artist Filip Hodas, shared in 2016.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: Snopes.com fact-check explicitly states that the video of a pink volcano eruption in New Zealand is false.  It clarifies that the video is digitally manipulated and is not an actual volcanic eruption. No evidence supports the existence of a naturally occurring "pink volcano".

final_result.explanation:
The claim that the image depicts an "actual 'pink volcano' erupting in New Zealand" is demonstrably false based on both internal and external evidence.  The internal analysis reveals a lack of visual evidence supporting this claim. The image shows a pink and purple smoke plume, which is not consistent with volcanic eruptions.  Furthermore, there's no contextual information within the image itself to suggest a location in New Zealand or a volcanic event. The internal assessment concludes the caption is inaccurate.

The external validation strengthens this conclusion significantly.  A reputable fact-checking website, Snopes.com, definitively debunks this claim.  Snopes confirms that the video (presumably related to the still image) showing a pink volcanic eruption is digitally manipulated.  Crucially, Snopes states that there is no record of naturally occurring volcanic eruptions producing bright pink smoke.  They explicitly attribute the video to the work of an artist, Filip Hodas, and its origin in 2016.  The external evidence provides strong corroboration and eliminates any reasonable doubt about the caption's accuracy.

There is complete agreement between the internal and external checks. Both indicate that the caption is inaccurate and misleading. The high confidence score of 10 reflects the strong evidence against the claim. The image itself does not show a volcano, and external fact-checking sources definitively prove that the video associated with this claim is digitally altered and not a real event. No ambiguities or discrepancies exist between internal analysis and external verification; both processes confirm the caption's inaccuracy. The visual evidence aligns with the findings of the external sources. The pink cloud formation in the image lacks the characteristics of a volcanic eruption. The absence of any geological features typically associated with a volcanic eruption in the image further supports the conclusion that the caption misrepresents the image's content. No further investigation or clarification is needed. The caption is demonstrably out of context and factually incorrect.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation processes strongly indicate that the caption is inaccurate and misleading. The image does not show a volcanic eruption, and reputable sources confirm the claim is based on a digitally manipulated video.
